meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny, folks! It's your favorite grog game reviewer here, and I'm thrilled to dive into the world of Songs of Conquest, a turn-based tactics anthology that's got everyone buzzing. Now, I know what you're thinking - what makes this game so special? Well, let me tell you, it's not just about the battles; it's about the heart.

While some critics might say that Songs of Conquest is just another indie release trying to fill the void left by Heroes of Might and Magic (ahem, Eurogamer), I'm here to tell you that this game is more than just a copycat. It's got soul, folks! And let me quote one of those fancy critics: "There's a lot of heart in this gorgeous turn-based tactics anthology..." Yes, please!

Now, I know some of you might be thinking, "Wait, what about the battles? Are they as punishing and uneven as some of these reviews suggest?" Well, my friends, let me tell you - the battles are indeed intense, but that's part of the charm. You'll need to strategize, adapt, and maybe even pray to the grog gods (that's a thing, right?) to emerge victorious.

But what about the graphics, you ask? Oh, boy! The pixel art is simply stunning. It's like stepping into a time machine and landing in the 90s all over again. I mean, who wouldn't want to play as a faction of chunky, chunky warriors with mustaches that could rival any hipster's?

Now, let me address those critics who think this game is just a rehashing of old ideas. Listen, folks - sometimes the best way to honor the classics is to pay homage while still adding your own personal touches. And Songs of Conquest does just that.

So, what's my verdict? Well, I'll leave it up to you to decide. But trust me when I say that this game is a golden example of turn-based strategy done right - with heart, humor, and a healthy dose of grog-tastic fun.

That's all for now, folks! Hippo Penny out!
